items.title: Deprecation warning for django 4.0 for  `providing_args `
items.body:
Hi,

I just saw that we have an upcoming deprecation in this package:

> site-packages\django_ses\signals.py:7: RemovedInDjango40Warning: The providing_args argument is deprecated. As it is purely documentational, it has no replacement. If you rely on this argument as documentation, you can move the text to a code comment or docstring.
  delivery_received = Signal(providing_args=["mail_obj", "delivery_obj", "raw_message"])


Maybe we should tackle this sooner than later 😃 

Best regards  
Ronny

items.title: Support for python 2.7.12
items.body: The recent releases require python 2.7.15 (defined in setup.py).  This causes pip to fail with the message `ERROR: No matching distribution found for django-ses==1.0.1` when attempting to install on python 2.7.12. This has caused some problems for use as we have some environments which still have an older version of python 2.7. Is there any reason this package can't support all versions of python 2.7?

items.title: AttributeError: 'SES' object has no attribute 'close'
items.body:
In upgrading `django-ses` to version `1.0.0`, we began seeing the following error when using `mail.get_connection` to send emails:
```python
AttributeError: 'SES' object has no attribute 'close'.
```
Here is the link to the code that uses this and ran into the issue: https://github.com/edx/license-manager/blob/aee7af851ddf87d9a2ba669693d0a9b995e51cb2/license_manager/apps/subscriptions/emails.py#L91-L102

The error doesn't seem to be having any effect on actual email sending as we are still seeing successful email deliveries from both the above code and django-ses email code in https://github.com/edx/edx-platform , but the exception is causing server errors in places that have not yet been wrapped with a try/except.

Is it possible to get a fix for this issue out soon? Thanks in advance

items.title: Need to update the signature version for authentication?
items.body:
Got this email from AWS today.

> Amazon Web Services currently supports Amazon SES API requests that are signed using Signature Version 3 and Signature Version 4 processes. Signature Version 4 further enhances the security around authentication and authorization of Amazon SES customers by using a signing key instead of your secret access key. To improve the security for our customers, beginning October 1, 2020, Amazon Signature Version 3 will be turned off (deprecated) in Amazon SES in favor of Signature Version 4.
> 
> Amazon SES customers who are still using Signature Version 3 must migrate to Signature Version 4 by September 30, 2020. After that, Amazon SES will only accept requests that are signed using Signature Version 4. For more information, see Signature Version 4 signing process [1].
> 
> What Happens if I Don't Make Updates?
> 
> Requests signed with Signature Version 3 that are made after September 30, 2020 will fail to authenticate with Amazon SES. Requesters will see errors stating that the request must be signed with Signature Version 4.
> 
> References:
> [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/signature-version-4.html
> 

Will this be handled by boto or we'll have to make any change?

items.title: Switch to cryptography for X509 certificate verification
items.body:
Issue #176 is annoying for Mac OS X users, partly because most of us likely use linux as our production target, so any deviation for setup instructions just causes issues and frustration.

I've taken a look at the logic around how M2Crypto is used and it appears that swapping to using `cryptography`'s X509 verification shouldn't take much work.

I'm opening the issue here to see if anyone would be willing to implement before my team does and also if they'd be up for testing it (we'll test but it's always nice having more). The change would also adjust the extra install to use cryptography, effectively removing M2Crypto from the project.

If that's not ideal, we can provide a callable into the library to all projects to use whichever x509 validator they'd like (just give us a function to call to get the certificate info based on the data), but I really hope we don't have to do that and so that won't be part of our code change.

items.title: InvalidClientTokenId with "AWS_SES_REGION_NAME = 'eu-central-1'"
items.body: Hi, I have been using Django-ses for a while and everything worked fine. When I wanted to move out of the ses sandbox, I realised that I had not set the region to "eu-central-1". After I did that, I cannot send emails anymore and instead get this error message: ``` boto.exception.BotoServerError: BotoServerError: 403 Forbidden Sender InvalidClientTokenId The security token included in the request is invalid. ec8c6de9-9bdc-48ab-8a35-50c8caf4fcd1 ``` Any idea what the problem is? Cheers, Gregor BTW: my settings.py looks like this: ``` DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL = '***@gmail.com' EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django_ses.SESBackend' with open('/etc/AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID.txt') as f: AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID = f.read().strip() with open('/etc/AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY.txt') as f: AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY = f.read().strip() AWS_SES_REGION_NAME = 'eu-central-1' AWS_SES_REGION_ENDPOINT = 'email.eu-central-1.amazonaws.com' ```

items.title: Track `requests` and `M2Crypto` as dependencies in an extras
items.body:
`requests` and `M2Crypto` are required for bounce message verification in [`django_ses/utils.py`](https://github.com/django-ses/django-ses/blob/master/django_ses/utils.py). However those packages are not tracked as dependencies of `django-ses` and have to be installed explicitly by the user. Those packages are then added to requirements.txt or Pipfile. The user could add comments in `requirements.txt` or `Pipfile`, but the comments could be inadvertently wiped out by automation tooling (e.g. `pip freeze` or `pipenv install`). So it's easy, for example, to forget why `M2Crypto` was added in the first place, then the user removes it and bounce message handling starts failing, at which point it's a bit too late.

I would suggest tracking those packages as a `bounce` extras in [`setup.py`](https://github.com/django-ses/django-ses/blob/master/setup.py), like described here: https://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setuptools.html#declaring-extras-optional-features-with-their-own-dependencies

Users who would like to use the bounce handling can then do `pip install django-ses[bounce]`

items.title: What are the methods supported by this application ?
items.body:
I went through all the documentation. 
There no chapter explaining the Django methods supported. Is that normal ? 
Can I send mass mails ? 
Is html_content supported ?
Is this example working ? 
```
from django.core import mail
connection = mail.get_connection()

# Manually open the connection
connection.open()

# Construct an email message that uses the connection
email1 = mail.EmailMessage(
    'Hello',
    'Body goes here',
    'from@example.com',
    ['to1@example.com'],
    connection=connection,
)
email1.send() # Send the email

# Construct two more messages
email2 = mail.EmailMessage(
    'Hello',
    'Body goes here',
    'from@example.com',
    ['to2@example.com'],
)
email3 = mail.EmailMessage(
    'Hello',
    'Body goes here',
    'from@example.com',
    ['to3@example.com'],
)

# Send the two emails in a single call -
connection.send_messages([email2, email3])
# The connection was already open so send_messages() doesn't close it.
# We need to manually close the connection.
connection.close()
```

items.title: Does it work for Django 1.11 and Python 3.6
items.body: I've got an error "ImportError: Module "django_ses" does not define a "SESBackend" attribute/class" when I try to send a email using this library. I hope to use this one.

items.title: Does the lib support Pythton 2?
items.body:
Hello,

I am currently trying to confirm a SNS subscription, but I always get:

```

TypeError
unicode argument expected, got 'str'
django_ses/utils.py in _get_bytes_to_sign at line 175
        outbytes = StringIO()
        for field_name in fields_to_sign:
            field_value = smart_str(self._data.get(field_name, ''),
                                    errors="replace")
            if field_value:
                outbytes.write(field_name)
                outbytes.write("\n")
                outbytes.write(field_value)
                outbytes.write("\n")
        return outbytes.getvalue()
```
I believe it happens because in Python 2.x strings are 'str' by default (what makes it necessary to refer to them as `u'somestring'`), while in Python 3.x strings are 'unicode' by default. Could this be considered an issue or the django-ses **intentionally** does not support Python 2?

items.title: Non-unicode log messages can break on sender name
items.body:
Hello! I work at edx.org, where we make use of this library to send bulk emails from educators to learners.

Recently, [we ran into an issue with some Spanish courses](https://openedx.atlassian.net/browse/EDUCATOR-1773). Specifically, [this logging statement](https://github.com/django-ses/django-ses/blob/v0.8.3.1/django_ses/__init__.py#L217-L222) causes a `UnicodeEncodeError` when `message.from_email` contains non-ascii characters. In our case, the `from_email` value is constructed as `{course_title} Course Staff <{some_valid_noreply_addr}>`, and for these courses, the titles contain accented vowels.

It's worth noting that the emails are sent without any issue, the only problem seems to be the logging statements as far as I can tell.

Here is a fairly minimal recreation taken from a pdb session I just ran:

```
(Pdb) from_addr
u'"\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3\xf3" Course Staff <asdasd-no-reply@example.com>'
(Pdb) print "send_messages.sent from='{}'".format(from_addr)
*** UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 1-15: ordinal not in range(128)
(Pdb) print u"send_messages.sent from='{}'".format(from_addr)
send_messages.sent from='"óóóóóóóóóóóóóóó" Course Staff <asdasd-no-reply@example.com>'
```

Would there be any drawback to making all log messages unicode by default? I'm happy to put together a PR if you'd like.

Thanks, and have a great weekend!

items.title: django-ses is unable to use ECS task roles, uses instance role instead (boto3 required?)
items.body:
Probably because django-ses is not using boto3 it can't use IAM Roles for ECS tasks feature.
Whenever it tries to send email it uses role from instance profile instead.
And if instance is not allowed to access SES we get permission errors.

IAM Roles for Tasks are described here: [http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/task-iam-roles.html](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/task-iam-roles.html)

django-amazon-ses is using boto3 and uses task role correctly.

To reproduce create ECS cluster without giving access to SES from instance role and then create ECS Service with role with SES access. Trying to send email with django-ses gives 403 error with explanation that instance role does not have access to SES.

items.title: No Python3 installables
items.body: Only the "binary" wheel for Python 2 was uploaded to PyPI, making v0.8.2 uninstallable on Python3.

items.title: ses_email_address: type object 'BaseCommand' has no attribute 'option_list' - django 1.10
items.body:
option_list in BaseCommand was deprecated in 1.8: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/howto/custom-management-commands/#django.core.management.BaseCommand.option_list

so ses_email_address command does not work.

items.title: Drop support for earlier versions of Django
items.body:
The changes in 14a7c79f453072936b1c50544db6a9cb8fb4e862 are not compatible with Django 1.6 and earlier (Using a list instead of `patterns` in Django 1.7 is undocumented but it will work).

However, the  tox file still tests for Django 1.3-1.7.

Would you accept a patch that dropped support for Django 1.7 and earlier? Django 1.8 LTS is currently the oldest supported version. Django 1.7 and earlier have not been supported since Django 1.9 was released in December 2015.

items.title: Sending stats admin URL doesn't work with Django 1.10
items.body:
Using the latest django_ses==0.8.0 from Pip. 

The django_ses urls.py include the following import:
    `from django.conf.urls.defaults import patterns, url`

With Django 1.10, this gives an `ImportError: No module named defaults`. This is because the code fails to import `patterns`, and then wrongly assumes that we're on Django < 1.4, which isn't the case.

items.title: DKIM signing steps in README unnecessary when enabled in SES
items.body:
Not sure why the section on DKIM is in the README, maybe it is an artifact from earlier?

Anyway, if you enable DKIM in the SES Console (and go through the verification steps) then Amazon will apply the DKIM signing (so you don't need the hassle with the keys).

items.title: Region settings are not strictly optional
items.body:
The readme says "additionally, you can specify an optional region". However, if you are outside the default region (which I think is us-east-1), AWS_SES_REGION_NAME and AWS_SES_REGION_ENDPOINT are required. Sending emails will fail with an unhelpful "Address not verified" error if these are omitted.

In my opinion, a quick mention of this case would improve the readme.

items.title: Missing migrations
items.body: I see that this app does not include the initial migrations. Is this intentional or am I missing something here?

I tried installing it with python 3.5 on ubuntu, using pip 8.1.1 but I keep getting this error:

I tried --no-cache-dir and then just removing ~/.cache/pip altogether. I also tried installing on a few other machines but none of their pip's can see 0.7.1.

items.title: Support for "IAM roles for EC2"
items.body:
Hi guys,

Is it possible to make this package support ["IAM roles for EC2"](http://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2012/06/11/Announcing-IAM-Roles-for-EC2-instances/) feature?

I think the workable change would be something like below:

**_Orginal**_

```
connection = SESConnection(
                aws_access_key_id=access_key_id,
                aws_secret_access_key=access_key,
                region=region)
```

**_Support for IAM**_

```
connection = boto.ses.connect_to_region(region=region) If aws_access_key_id is None or aws_secret_access_key is None else boto.ses.connect_to_region(aws_access_key_id=access_key_id, aws_secret_access_key=access_key, region=region)
```

items.title: Request: Support for SES SMTP
items.body:
Hi, 
Thanks so much for this great package! I've used it on a couple of sites and it works like a charm.
My client wants me to use the smtp version of ses - is there any way to do that with this package?

Thanks!

items.title: Add support for handling bounced emails via a web-hook
items.body:
SES allows you to handle bounced email messages via the SNS which can ping a URL with the JSON data.

I'd like a view that can handle the bounced data, save the info in the DB and fire a signal when a bounced message is recieved.

See: http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/NotificationsViaSNS.html

items.title: Support Python 2.6
items.body:
SESBackend.send_messages use timedelta.total_seconds() when calculating the rate throttling delay (line 142 of django_ses.__init__.py in the current PyPI package). This method is new in Python 2.7, so I am getting AttributeError under Python 2.6. How about doing the calculation that total_seconds() does instead of using the shortcut? The calculation is in the Python docs:

http://docs.python.org/library/datetime.html#datetime.timedelta.total_seconds

```
timedelta.total_seconds()

    Return the total number of seconds contained in the duration. Equivalent to (td.microseconds + (td.seconds + td.days * 24 * 3600) * 10**6) / 10**6 computed with true division enabled.

    Note that for very large time intervals (greater than 270 years on most platforms) this method will lose microsecond accuracy.

    New in version 2.7.
```

items.title: PyPI v0.2 and Github tag v0.2 don't match
items.body: I'm going to roll a v0.3 release once I can verify that the tests do indeed pass, but want to bring it up that the tag was made in January by the package on PyPI was created last November.

items.title: Version calculation in setup.py isn't correct
items.body:
Installing the latest version (0.2.0) results in a package name of:
django-ses-.join-str-x-.for.x.in.VERSION-

The following change in setup.py fixes the problem:
VERSION = '.'.join(version_line.split(' = ')[-1][1:-2].split(', '))

items.title: Django version to support
items.body: Should django be listed in requirements section of the docs? And if so, which versions are we supporting? I have only tried this on 1.3.

items.title: Document how to setup SES dashboard
items.body:
Currently there's no documentation on how to setup the dashboard view.

EDIT: Sorry but I mean better documentation like example of how it should be done in urls.py

items.title: broken with boto 2.1.0
items.body:
If I bump to boto 2.1.0 django_ses breaks:

```
>>> from django.core.mail import send_mail
>>> send_mail('subject', 'message', 'example@domain.com', ['user@domain.com'])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/opt/virtualenvs/proj/src/django/django/core/mail/__init__.py", line 59, in send_mail
    fail_silently=fail_silently)
  File "/opt/virtualenvs/proj/src/django/django/core/mail/__init__.py", line 41, in get_connection
    return klass(fail_silently=fail_silently, **kwds)
  File "/opt/virtualenvs/proj/lib/python2.6/site-packages/django_ses/__init__.py", line 22, in __init__
    SESConnection.DefaultHost)
AttributeError: type object 'SESConnection' has no attribute 'DefaultHost'
>>> import boto
>>> boto.__version__
'2.1.0'
>>> import django_ses
>>> django_ses.__version__
'0.2'
```

items.title: "Email address is not verified" for verified email
items.body: TBH, I'm not sure where this bug is coming from, Boto, SES or my own configuration. Here it is though: BotoServerError at /accounts/signup/ BotoServerError: 400 Bad Request Sender MessageRejected Email address is not verified. 9360bdd6-c549-11e0-82fb-b9b4121fdb69 $ ./manage.py ses_email_address -l Fetching list of verified emails: notifier@gun.io Settings.py: EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django_ses.SESBackend' EMAIL_FROM = 'notifier@gun.io' EMAIL_HOST_USER='notifier@gun.io' DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL='notifier@gun.io' SERVER_EMAIL='notifier@gun.io' Went through the notification confirmation email from Amazon.. so why the rejected message?

items.title: No way to change the return-path/source
items.body:
According to [FAQ #39](http://aws.amazon.com/ses/faqs/#39) in order to change where bounce messages are sent you have to change the source parameter. That's why I came up with this patch that allows you to change the source parameter, https://gist.github.com/1105465.

Example Usage:

`msg = EmailMultiAlternatives(subject, message_text, from_email, [to])
msg.attach_alternative(message_html, "text/html")
msg.return_path = 'foo@bar.com'  # The address I want the bounce message to go to
msg.send()`

items.title: Clarify documentation for use with built-in views
items.body: It may be helpful to note in the documentation that DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL should be explicitly set in your settings.py if you want to take advantage of built-in views that send mail. It's a PITA gotcha.

items.title: Remove django from required package
items.body:
Hi,
Thank you for your piece of software, i'm using it production and it's so simple.
BTW, today i had to upgrade django-ses in order to stay up-to-date with my requirements, and i noticed that django-ses installed django==1.2.5 within. This is quite dangerous because it may breaks lot of sites - not all sites have migrated to 1.2.5, which implies to modify AJAX script in order to handle CSRF.
Can you remove this dependency, please ?
Cheers.
